People who ask such questions are usually people who have never been to China.Many foreigners who have not been to China always think China just like Chinese 1980s:Poor ,backward,low Education level,etc Most foreigners don't really know how developed China is now, but some people do know it and just don't want to admit it.Especially in southeast Asia,the Chinese have really boosted their tourism industry,however,Chinese people are often discriminated against when they travel there(sorrry ,just my own experience not everybody).May be it just like that a poor neighbor or relatives make a fortune suddenly……em… SORRY. Off topic .Just complain  Let’s return to the topic “Does China have internet?” The answer is : Yes ,we have internet . However, there's something special about our internet.In our habits ,we divide them into internal and external networks.In a nutshell,the networks inside China are called internal networks, while those outside China are called external networks.It's like a wall,we joke call it “长城（The Great Wall）” Someone might think it just like locking up the country.But as you can see, how developed is China's economy now.In fact, the internal networks can meet the needs of ordinary people.We have all kinds of websites that can meet our daily needs. We can also see the world through various channels. So can we surf the external networks inside China ?? Yes.We have a ladder to climb over the wall ,it called VPN.But over the wall is illegal in China,because someone can use this for illegal activities. There are also many people who have over the wall for academic purposes or for reference to some foreign literature. I don't judge whether this is good or bad,in a word , a lot of people around me who don't know how to over the wall .In fact, ordinary people like us,the internal networks can meet our daily needs completely. One of my friend returned after 2 years abroad ,she said domestic technology is updating too fast.People who have been to China know what is China like now,people whose views on China remain in the past,I say ten thousand words also considered bragging. Seeing is better than hearing. That’s all .Bless~~

First of all, what is “internet”? “Inter” means between. The opposite is “Intra”, meaning within. “Net” is short for network. So an “internet” is a network between different systems. Originally, “an internet” was just a network between a few different computers very close to each other. Overtime these “internets” around the world have grown bigger and bigger into one single “internet”. “The internet”. So, if your question is “Does China have access to THE internet?” Then the answer is: sort of… China has something called the great firewall, part of the “golden shield project” (金盾工程), which blocks access to a long list of websites designated by the communist party. When a website request is made within China and goes through one of the three main exchange servers in China, a black-listed request is immediately ignored and returns “page cannot be found”. (The website is blocked) However, a VPN can be used, which requests the Chinese exchange server to go to some non-black-listed site and then from there, once beyond the great firewall, requests the information you’re really after. So, can you access the internet in China? Yes. Does the government want you to access the internet? No. Is this access to the internet unreliable and prone to government shutdowns whenever it feels like it? Yes. Can you access the internet by default without any (illegal) software? No. So if you don’t have a VPN or some other sneaky way of getting past the great firewall, you are left with China’s default filtered collection of websites. This is not the internet, a more appropriate name is an “intranet”. A network within a system, not open to the rest of the network.

It’s fast and cheap but restricted to access to foreign social network websites, the famous newspaper websites, YouTube and all kinds of porn sites. When I traveled in the Philippines, I was stunned at how much they pay for the internet and how unreliable and slow the internet was there. One can easily spend a few thousand pesos on their phone bills for data. My friends who live in the States pay a monthly average of 165 dollars on a triple package of cable, internet, and phone. There are state-of-art telecom infrastructures in China. Chinese tech giant Huawei is already one of the largest telecom equipment manufacturers in the world. China doesn't need to import the equipment so that the telecom costs are not expensive. The Central Government persistently require the telecom companies to lower their service price. Thus, the telecom companies mainly are meant to be the service provider of the public instead of yearning solely for money and profit. Now though I use two phone numbers as a big chunk of the population does, I only end up spending about 40 RMB per month. That is less than 6 dollars. Let me tell you why. Tencent is the largest tech company in Asia and it started with an IM service called QQ. It successfully captured the attention of youngsters and matures alike. At its peak, its MAU was at 800 million. Then on January 21, 2011, Tencent released WeChat which is by far their most successful product, has an average MAU at 1 billion. Of course, the biggest revenue of Tencent is actually from the gaming industry. The mobile MOBA game, King’s Glory aka Mobile Legends, became an instant hit worldwide and got people so addicted to it. No wonder, Chinese netizens often say, Pony Ma, the founder, and CEO of Tencent, is most capable of making money from primary students. Because they pay a lot for the skins and weapons on the game. Tencent wants more. So it collaborated with the 2nd largest Chinese telecom company, China Unicom, and offered the kind of telecom service which covers all their data costs when people use Tencent’s apps. It’s called Tencent Wang Ka( King Simcard), and that’s my second sim. Here is a picture depicting the Tencent Wang Ka. It says using all apps from Tencent with free data collaborated with China Unicom.  Why do I still use the first one? Because that number’s bundled with all kinds of services I get in China, as the debit bank card, Alipay, all kinds of apps and so on. Abandoning the old number just makes me have a big hassle in my life. So I just need to pay the basic service fee at around 10 RMB(1.4 USD). For that much, I still get free incoming calls, free texts, and some few hundreds of megabites data. That makes sense when you hear Chinese people really like to use dual-sim smartphones. Even Apply has that feature in its latest iPhones specially catering to the Chinese market. In conclusion, China’s current accessibility now is not good but the internet here is really cheap and fast. With the VPN installed on your phone and computer, get ready to surf the web freely with a cost about 100 USD.

I find this question to be very amusing. As funny as this is, I can see how one might be confused. China has many online platforms blocked throughout the country, such as Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, etc. However, just because China has what is called a “firewall”, this obviously does not mean that they do not have access to internet. The fact that these websites are blocked alone gives you knowledge that they have internet, otherwise they would have no need to block them. Though they have strong censorship, most of the time they have their own equivalent to these sites. Honestly, if you get passed the fact that China censors an unnecessary amount of things, you’ll see that their internet and technology is actually much more advanced than ours is. Of course, we have apple pay that we can use here and there at stores (but only those that allow it). China has taken this a step forward, and way earlier than us. They use technology for EVERYTHING there using their main internet platform, WeChat. All stores have QR codes that you can scan through your app on your phone in order to pay for all your things, it even works at self-checkouts at grocery stores and smaller street markets! China’s form of internet may be different than ours, but its very advanced and interesting nontheless!

We have the Chininternet LMBO. In China most big social medias are blocked as well as news websites and search engines, it’s because they don’t comply with China’s law that require them to host their servers in China. Many people believe that it’s because of censorship, and it is, but it’s not the only reason. For example Bing and Yahoo will give results that don’t preach the Chinese government narrative on things, yet they aren’t blocked because they host the Chinese version of their website in China. For each website that is blocked in China there is a domestic equivalent anyway, only it isn’t always up to par. For example no Chinese trust Baidu (Chinese Google) for anything serious because its results are of poor quality and known to be biased (they take payments to put websites on the first page), but people still use it for casual searches. Something that is bigger in China than elsewhere is livestreaming. In China there is stiff competition between different platforms that rise and fall overnight, hundreds of millions of people watch livestreamers everyday on their commute to work or during lunchbreak, can be on any topic from gaming to food to telling stories to topic-based podcasts, etc… Overall the Chinese internet is its own ecosystem cut off from the rest of the world. See it as a good thing, otherwise you would probably see Chinese speakers swarming every major websites and overwhelming English speakers. Lots of Chinese use VPNs to access the global internet, but it’s still a tiny fraction of the population.

China saw the number of online audiovisual content users reach 901 million as of this June, accounting for 95.8 percent of total internet users, with the industry grossing a revenue of 454.13 billion yuan ($67.43 billion) in 2019, according to the latest research.  The report on the development of China's internet audio-and-video industry was released on October 12, 2020 at the 8th China Internet Audio and Video Convention, which was held in Chengdu, southwest China's Sichuan Province. For the first time, the annual report introduced the scale of the online audiovisual content market. It showed that the emerging industry had 454.13 billion yuan in revenue in 2019, becoming the core pillar of the online entertainment industry. This year's report also showed that more internet users have turned to online information services and sources for recreation amid the coronavirus pandemic, leading to further growth in the number of online audiovisual content users.  Chinese users of online audiovisual content reached 901 million as of this June, accounting for 95.8 percent of the total internet users. /CFP As of June this year, the number of short-video users hit 818 million, taking up 87 percent of all netizens, with an average time of 110 minutes spent on short video apps per person each day, exceeding that of instant messaging services, the report showed. Zhou Jie, executive deputy secretary-general of the China Netcasting Services Association, believes that short-video services have expanded its functions to a variety of fields, such as news and education, rather than just serving as entertainment. According to the report, as of June, the number of livestream services users stood at 562 million, of which e-commerce livestream users make up 309 million. E-commerce livestream was the fastest-growing internet application in 2020. Additionally, e-commerce livestream has played an important role in poverty alleviation and disaster-relief aid, especially in the battle against the pandemic, it said. Source: China sees more than 900 million online audiovisual content users

Yes China has internet, but it is not as you know it. The Chinese internet has replaced much of the western social internet sites with Chinese versions, and the government basically denies access to western internet sites to supposedly support the local versions. It is all just a big in china as it is here. In fact in some ways they are more advanced that western use. For example if you have Chinese banking money, you can rock up to a city push bike rack, scan the Q-Code, to rent a bike and ride. It is complex to get setup but it can be done. You can do similar in the west, but it is via a multitude of applications and one all just one service, making it a lot harder. The major difference is the Chinese government does have censorship, though the Chinese people accept this, with the thought that the government is protecting them. Which is another reason why local Chinese social media is preferred. The Government can exert control of it. Then there is this social ‘game’ that rates people by how good a citizen they are, and this has effects on a lot of real world events too. TL;DR; Yes they have internet, and is just as big, if not bigger. But it is totally different experience. It also helps if you can read Chinese. :-)

I have lived in China for nineteen years. When I was born in 1999, many Chinese internet companies like Tencent(founded in 1998) and Alibaba(founded in 1999) just had established for a short time. At that moment, even most of the Chinese people don’t know what is the computer. When I was in primary school, my family had the first computer which is so slow that I can just play tiny games.We go on the Internet by using telephone line at that time. So I can answer your question by YES, China have had the Internet for many years, However, Chinese Internet is different from other countries so that many foreigners can’t be customed to it.For example, you can’t use google or facebook in China because of the existence of GFW(great fire wall). GFW can pervent the requests to some site like google which may let some people believe that China haven’t Internet. Unfortunately, you can’t use quora in China yet(I’m using VPN to answer your question).

Yes, just a bit different. We were well prepared to travel through the closed internet of China, as we’ve heard. But - we were surprised to the find out the following cases: As a traveler using a non-Chinese company for my cell’s internet, I could enjoy complete freedom to use any website, app or anything via the open web.If we used a local wifi - we couldn't use blocked apps like Facebook, Waze, Google, Whatsapp, instagram etc. We had to use Chinese apps and websites. (Or - turn on a VPN)Locals in China have no access to Google, Facebook, WhatsApp, western websites and apps. Those websites are completely blocked and cannot be accessed. Some Chinese use VPN to get access.So you do have internet in China, but if you consider traveling you have to check for websites which are open in China before traveling. (Btw, China is spectacular!)

Unfortunately the answer is NO. China is one of the poorest countries. Usually there will be one or two internet center in the capital city of each province. All activities online (email, search engine, webpage browsing…) is monitored and the cost is ridiculous for common citizens. I heard there is a 50% discount for the rich or the government officers, but there is no way I know the truth (I am one of the poor). No mention if you live far away from the capital… For some it takes about two months to get to capital city from their home town, since there is no car, no plane, even no oxcart. The best vehicle we use, bicycles. I have to log off… The maximum time online for each citizen is 60 min per year. I want to save some for December. :D

It depends on what you mean by “internet”…Technically speaking, There is no direct internet access in China…Chinese “internet users” operate behind the Great Fire Wall and requests for access to internet resources get routed through Australia or some other backbone provider outside of China…. They can freely access web sites and other services that are behind the fire wall…. What China has is an internal network through which approved resources on the internet can be accessed…. Think of this way…before the American public had direct internet access, there were BBS services and then AOL and CompuServ came along. If you were an AOL user you had access to AOL content then they later added a link to the internet. The “internet” in China is more likely to like AOL. Let's call it China Net. You have access to China Net. You can access the internet through China Net but not directly. Your requests are approved and filtered. You need a vpn in China to get around the fire wall and access the internet directly…this is discussed at my subscription web site www.thisismychina.com

No, It has a wide range Intranet within 1.4 billion users. Most of internet products , popular in the rest part of whole world, are blocked outside , and replaced with correspondent domestic version: Google search for Baidu, Twitter/Instagram/Facebook for Weibo, Whatsapp for Wechat, Gmail for 163 mail(generally Chinese don’t use email),no Wikipedia Chinese Version, Android cellphone withot Google Service, Appstore don’t provides apps prohibited by goverment……

They do have internet, but don’t have access to Google, Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Whatsapp, and iCloud…which, technically could render the internet semi-useless for you. Though they photocopy most of the above mentioned website and service and create their own ‘in-wall’ version, ridiculous censorship are imposed by these website and service. For example, my account with one website was locked for numerous times just just because my latest novel regarding a legend historical story recites word “riot” in Chinese for several times - for god’s sake, that is referred to a riot took place more than 1200 years ago! When my friends in China talk about how great China is these days, I think about this repeatedly: if a country is so afraid of its people using ‘riot’, even for describing a historical event 1200 years ago, then, is the country really great?

China doesn't really have the internet as those outside China know it. It is more like a China intranet as many foreign websites are blocked, even those that are not to do with national security, political, or otherwise. Downloads like updates to software are also throttled. China has stated previously that for the product to be distributed within China, the source code has to be provided to the Chinese government + it has to be on a local Chinese server*. Now since many foreign companies won't do that, downloading any of those will take hours. If you check the speed of your internet within China, you will find it extraordinarily slow if you go to websites out of the country. Painfully and tediously slow slow slow……… but websites hosted in China will be very fast. Sounds like China Intranet and not internet to me. *Please do correct me if this understanding is erroneous.

I have lived in China since I was born. I can tell you for sure that there is no Internet in most parts of China. As you can see, few Chinese people appear on the Internet, but we all know thatChina has a population of 1.4 billion, so if there is an Internet, then there can be only a small number of Internet users, so most of China is free of the Internet. According to reliable sources, China has less than 1 million Internet users, while India, with a population of 1.3 billion, has more than 600 million Internet users. This is an amazing number. On the Internet, I can make it very clear that India has surpassed China by more than a little. So, why can I surf the Internet? In fact, 80% of China's netizens are in Beijing, the other 15% in Shanghai, I am currently studying at Tsinghua University in Beijing, this is the best university in China, the school provides an internal network, so that us students can access the Internet. Although Tsinghua University is the best university in China, Tsinghua University lags behind many Indian universities in the world rankings, and it is difficult for China to surpass India's education level in a short period of time.

That should give you some ideas about how’s the Internet doing in China :) And also, you don't see many Chinese on Facebook, Twitter, quora etc and that's because these sites are blocked in China.

Does China have internet? This is not a troll or stupid question! China (and North Korea, among other countries) have selective, limited and controlled internal networks that may or may not allow some Internet access. The Internet as most Westerners know it (I prefer the spelling as Internet) was created as a world-wide, unfettered system available to all. Whatdoes www.* mean? This exclusion works both ways. Outside China, you cannot access many Chinese websites. For example, many network sites hosted in China require that you register your real name, have a registered or verifiable address in China, and a China telecom-issued phone number. China has a constrained, truncated and diminished part of the Internet. It is a network - with Chinese characteristics - Chinanet. Chinanet is not the Internet.

The answer is NO. Then you may wonder how you see answers from people living in China. The Department of Internet handles these stuff. The steps are listed below: know online forums and the topics, e.g. Quora, from hard-copies of newspaper.Subscript forums and topics, e.g. China topic in Quora.Receive updates through mails.Mail applications to open account if needed.Mail answers or comments to the Department of Internet.Officers of Department of Internet publish the content in nearby countries with Internet, e.g. Korea.

Barely. All services provided by Google are blocked (that includes the search engine, but also Google Maps, Youtube, Hangouts IM, and pretty much any developer API you may or may not know of that will break partly or entirely most Westerner websites, such as Google Fonts and Analytics). Same goes for all Facebook services: including but not only, Instagram and Whatsapp. Aside from that, any website hosted outside of China is slowed down dramatically due to the filtering of the Internet. In general, all the other information, social and messaging apps, are also blocked: Yahoo, Tumblr, Wordpress.com, Viber, Vimeo, Daily Motion, SoundCloud, Netflix, all US and UK newspapers. So are all major pornographic websites. Of course, all those services have local equivalents, all available only in Chinese, and all used only by Chinese people. Oh yeah, but even the local services, like for instance the WeChat messaging app, will not deliver messages containing keywords that are banned by the government, should you be foolish enough to try to discuss them.

I have just spent a week in some of the major cities in China. It is an amazing modern advanced society with wonderful people. Everybody seems to have a good quality smartphone. They are way more advanced than the west in many ways. The internet is a version that is not connected to the outside world very much - many western websites are not blocked, so a type of large ‘Intranet’ might be a better way to describe it. If you mean by ‘Internet’ ‘World Wide Web’ then you could say it is not world wide. Baidu is the search engine - gives limited western results. Wechat is used widely as an equivalent to Whatsapp or Facebook. Wechat can be used in the west to communicate with people in China. So - technologically very advanced while a different idea of the internet than we have in the West.
